title: R44392
content: The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) covers 72.5% of the premium for eligible taxpayers, who are responsible for the remaining 27.5%. It can be used towards qualified health insurance and is refundable and advanceable. Eligibility is based on receiving certain benefits under the Trade Adjustment Assistance program or being aged 55-64 and receiving payments from the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. Eligible individuals for the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) include those receiving benefits under the Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) program and individuals aged 55-64 receiving payments from the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. TAA assists workers who lose their jobs due to international trade, with eligibility determined by the U.S. Department of Labor. Workers can qualify for HCTC by receiving Trade Readjustment Allowance (TRA) or Reemployment Trade Adjustment Assistance (RTAA) benefits. Cash payments for workers enrolled in TAA-sponsored training and who have exhausted UI eligibility. TRA payments start the week after UI eligibility ends, with a maximum of 130 weeks for UI and TRA combined. HCTC eligibility for workers collecting TRA or UI. RTAA provides wage supplement for workers aged 50+ in qualified lower-wage employment, paying 50% of wage difference for up to two years. ATAA is a wage-insurance program similar to RTAA. HCTC eligibility limited to TRA, RTAA, or ATAA cash benefit recipients. Individuals receiving PBGC-paid pensions are eligible for the HCTC if they are at least 55 years old. The PBGC takes over defined-benefit pension plans to protect participants' interests or if employers demonstrate financial inability to continue. PBGC uses plan assets and insurance reserves to pay pensions to former workers and their survivors. Individuals receiving PBGC-paid pensions are eligible for the HCTC if they are at least 55 years old. Eligibility for the HCTC is limited for individuals enrolled in certain health plans or programs, such as Medicare, FEHBP, Medicaid, or CHIP. Additionally, individuals cannot be eligible for Medicare Part A or coverage through the U.S. military health system to qualify for the HCTC. To be eligible for the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC), individuals must not be enrolled in Medicare Part A, FEHBP, Medicaid, CHIP, or Tricare. They also cannot be incarcerated or claimed as a dependent by another taxpayer. The HCTC can be used for health insurance covering the taxpayer, spouse, and dependents. Family members can receive the HCTC for up to two years after certain events. The HCTC can only cover part of the premium for qualified health insurance. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) can be used for qualified health insurance for up to two years after specific events. Eligible taxpayers can only claim the HCTC for certain coverage categories, including COBRA, group health plans, individual health insurance, and coverage funded by a VEBA. Other coverage options are available only if the state has established them. State-qualified health plans, identified by letter designations, offer various coverage options such as state-based continuation coverage, state high-risk pools, and plans for state employees. These plans must provide four consumer protections as required by statute. State-qualified health plans must provide four consumer protections, including guaranteed issue, coverage for preexisting conditions, equal premiums for qualifying individuals, and similar benefits. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) program ensures that qualifying applicants cannot be denied coverage, regardless of preexisting conditions. Premiums must be equal for all individuals, and benefits must be similar. Certain types of coverage are not considered qualified health insurance under the program. The IRS administers the HCTC program, with involvement from federal and state agencies. The HCTC program involves various federal and state agencies, including the IRS, Treasury, DOL, PBGC, and state workforce agencies. These entities work together to administer the advance payment system for the HCTC, identify eligible individuals, and provide information to job seekers about available benefits. State-level entities such as departments of insurance and health agencies also play a role in the program. Taxpayers can receive advance payments for the credit monthly or claim it when filing their tax returns. The HCTC is refundable, allowing taxpayers to receive the full amount they are eligible for, regardless of their tax liability. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) allows taxpayers to receive the full amount they are eligible for, even if they have little or no tax liability. Claiming the HCTC may affect eligibility for other tax credits, except for the premium tax credit under the Affordable Care Act. In 2013, 13,693 tax returns claimed the HCTC, totaling approximately $52.3 million. Taxpayers can claim the HCTC by completing Form 8885 and attaching it to their Form 1040. The HCTC program confirms eligibility, invoices for the taxpayer's share of the premium, and sends payment to health insurance plans after receiving payments from individuals.
